### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 54 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: I think I cannot open my address more.appropriately than by stating my experience in my.long connection with the reform movement..It was during the great railroad strike of 1877 that.I first became interested in what is known as the.“Labor Question.”^1 I then thought as many thousands.of earnest, sincere people think, that the aggregate.power operating in human society, known as.government, could be made an instrument in the.hands of the oppressed to alleviate their sufferings..But a closer study of the origin, history and tendency.of governments convinced me that this was a mistake..I came to understand how organized governments.used their concentrated power to retard progress by.their ever-ready means of silencing the voice of.discontent if raised in vigorous protest against the.machinations of the scheming few, who always did,.always will and always must rule in the councils of.nations where majority rule is recognized as the only.means of adjusting the affairs of the people..I came to understand that such concentrated.power can be always wielded in the interest of the few.and at the expense of the many. Government in its.last analysis is this power reduced to a science..Governments never lead; they follow progress. When.the prison, stake or scaffold can no longer silence the.voice of the protesting minority, progress moves on a.step, but not until then..I will state this contention in another way: I.learned by close study that it made no difference what.fair promises a political party, out of power, might.make to the people in order to secure their.confidence, when once securely established in control.of the affairs of society; that they were after all but.human with all the human attributes of the politician..Among these are: First, to remain in power at all.hazards; if not individually, then those holding.essentially the same views as the administration must.be kept in control. Second, in order to keep in power,.it is necessary to build up a powerful machine; one.strong enough to crush all opposition and silence all.vigorous murmurs of discontent, or the party.machine might be smashed and the party thereby lose.control..When I came to realize the faults, failings,.shortcomings, aspirations and ambitions of fallible.man, I concluded that it would not be the safest nor.best policy for society, as a whole, to entrust the.management of all its affairs, with all their manifold.deviations and ramifications in the hands of finite.man, to be managed by the party which happened to.come into power, and therefore was the majority.party, nor did it then, nor does it now make one.particle of difference to me what a party out of power.may promise; it does not tend to allay my fears of.[what] a party, when entrenched and securely seated.in power might do to crush opposition, and silence.the voice of the minority, and thus retard the onward.step of progress..My mind is appalled at the thought of a political.party having control of all the details that go to make.up the sum total of our lives. Think of it for an.instant, that the party in power shall have all.authority to dictate the kind of books that shall be.used in our schools and universities; government.officials editing, printing, and circulating our.literature, histories, magazines and press, to say.nothing of the thousand and one activities of life that.a people engage in, in a civilized society..To my mind, the struggle for liberty is too great.and the few steps we have gained have been won at.too great a sacrifice, for the great mass of the people.of this twentieth century to consent to turn over to.any political party the management of our social and.industrial affairs. For all who are at all familiar with.history know that men will abuse power when they.possess it. For these and other reasons, I, after careful.study, and not through sentiment, turned from a.sincere, earnest, political Socialist^2 to the non-.political phase of Socialism—Anarchism^3 —because.in its philosophy I believe I can find the proper.conditions for the fullest development of the.individual units in society, which can never be the.case under government restrictions..(^1) The question of how to preserve the rights of the worker in an.industrial society.(^2) One who espouses a belief that the production and distribution of.goods should be controlled by the government.(^3) A belief that opposes any form of authority in society
Question: It can reasonably be inferred from the passage that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place only when
Choices:
  A: masses of people are well versed in political history.
  B: political parties become committed to reform.
  C: fewer political parties are competing for people’s votes.
  D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
Response 0:
  The correct answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.

The passage suggests that Parsons believes that positive social change will occur when individuals and minority groups, rather than political parties, are able to effectively voice their concerns and compel governments to take action. He argues that political parties are prone to abusing power and that their promises should not be trusted, indicating that he does not believe that positive change can be achieved through traditional political means. Instead, he advocates for the non-political phase of Socialism, Anarchism, which emphasizes the importance of individual units in society and opposes government restrictions. Therefore, option D is the best answer.
Response 1:
  The correct answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.

Parsons believes that governments do not lead progress, but rather follow it. He states that progress is made when the voice of the protesting minority can no longer be silenced by the government's means of suppression. Therefore, it can be inferred that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place only when vocal individuals and minority groups are able to effectively compel governments to address their concerns and push for change.

The other options are not supported by the passage. There is no mention of the importance of political history (Option A) or political parties becoming committed to reform (Option B). While Parsons does mention the role of political parties in retarding progress (Option C), he does not suggest that fewer political parties competing for people's votes would lead to positive social change.
Response 2:
  The correct answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.

The passage suggests that Parsons believes that positive social change will come about through the efforts of vocal individuals who protest against the machinations of the scheming few who rule in the councils of nations. He argues that governments never lead, they follow progress, and that progress is only made when the voices of protesting minorities cannot be silenced. Therefore, it can be inferred that Parsons believes that positive social change will take place only when vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.

The other options are not supported by the passage. There is no mention of masses of people being well versed in political history (A), political parties becoming committed to reform (B), or fewer political parties competing for people's votes (C) as factors that will lead to positive social change.
Response 3:
  The correct answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.

The passage suggests that Parsons believes that positive social change will occur when individuals and minority groups raise their voices in protest against oppressive governments and demand change. He argues that governments tend to silence dissent and retard progress, but that vocal protests can force them to address the concerns of the people. Therefore, option D is the best answer.

The other options are not supported by the passage. Option A is not mentioned in the passage, and option B is actually rejected by Parsons, who argues that political parties cannot be trusted to bring about positive change. Option C is also not mentioned in the passage, and it is not clear how fewer political parties competing for votes would necessarily lead to positive social change.
Response 4:
  The correct answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.

Parsons believes that governments are not likely to lead progress, but rather follow it. He states that progress is made when the voice of the protesting minority can no longer be silenced by the government. Therefore, it can be inferred that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place when vocal individuals and minority groups are able to effectively compel governments to address their concerns and push for change.

The other options are not supported by the passage. There is no mention of the importance of people being well-versed in political history (A) or political parties becoming committed to reform (B). While Parsons does mention the role of political parties in retarding progress, he does not suggest that fewer political parties competing for people's votes would lead to positive social change (C).
Response 5:
  The correct answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.

Parsons believes that governments are not inclined to lead progress, but instead follow it. He argues that governments will only make changes when the voice of the protesting minority can no longer be silenced. This implies that positive social change will occur when individuals and minority groups vocally demand change and put pressure on governments to address their concerns.

Therefore, option D is the best answer. It is not necessarily the case that positive social change will occur when the masses of people are well-versed in political history (A), or when political parties become committed to reform (B). Nor does the passage suggest that fewer political parties competing for people's votes (C) would necessarily lead to positive social change.

He argues that governments are prone to abuse their power and that it is futile to rely on political parties to bring about change. Instead, he believes that change will come about through the actions of individuals who are willing to speak out and challenge the status quo.

There is no evidence in the passage to suggest that Parsons believes that positive social change will come about through the education of the masses (A), the commitment of political parties to reform (B), or the reduction of political parties competing for votes (C).

Parsons believes that governments never lead, they follow progress. He states that progress moves on a step when the prison, stake, or scaffold can no longer silence the voice of the protesting minority. ### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 55 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Large competitors are often viewed as a major.threat for startups and small companies; big.companies have more financial resources and greater.scale, market power and brand awareness than.smaller ones. However, our research finds that a.smaller brand can actually benefit if consumers can.see the competitive threat it faces from a larger.organization..When a U.S.-based ice cream chain with about 1,400 stores moved within 50 steps of a J.P. Licks ice.cream store in Newton, Massachusetts, some people.expected that J.P. Licks, a small, locally owned.company, would be beaten out of the Newton market..But consumers rallied around J.P. Licks, and the.national chain later closed its nearby location. When.the owner of the Los Angeles-based coffee store chain.The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf could not stop a large.coffee shop chain from moving in next door, he was.surprised to see his sales shoot up—so much so that.he started proactively colocating new stores next to.large chain ones..These examples are not anomalies. In six lab and.field studies, we explored the effects of having a large,.dominant competitor and found that highlighting a.large competitor’s size and close proximity can help.smaller brands, instead of harming them. Compared.to when they are in competition with brands that are.similar to them in size or when consumers view them.outside of a competitive context, small brands see.consumer support go up when they are faced with a.competitive threat from large brands. This support.translates into higher purchase intention, more.purchases and more favorable online reviews..As part of our research, we conducted a field study.at an independent bookstore in Cambridge,.Massachusetts. Upon entering the bookstore, 163.prospective shoppers were exposed to one of three.versions of an in-store ad, emphasizing either the.store’s large competitors, small competitors or no.competition. Shoppers who read the “large.competitors” version were told that the store’s main.competitors are large corporations that have the.ability to put small businesses such as this bookstore.out of business. The “small competitors” version.indicated the store’s main competitors are other.locally owned small bookstores in Cambridge. In the.“no competition” version, participants were given no.information about the competitive environment..Shoppers were then given a $5 coupon, coded with.the in-store ad version they read. Analyzing.shoppers’ sales receipts and the number of redeemed.coupons, we found that shoppers were significantly.more likely to make a purchase after reading the.“large competitors” version of the in-store ad,.compared to the “small competitors” version or the.“no competition” version. They also purchased more.items and spent more money at the store, compared.to shoppers reading the “small competitors” or “no.competition” versions. These results suggest that.framing the competitive game and emphasizing a.competitive narrative against a larger company can.help a small establishment—and spur consumers to.make a purchase that supports the smaller.competitor..In subsequent studies, we tested this “framing-.the-game” effect in various contexts and product.categories and further found that support for a large.brand decreases when consumers view it as being in.competition with a smaller brand. In one study, we.asked participants to assess two hypothetical rival tire.shops, “Tire World” and “Tire Planet,” under three.conditions—small vs. large, small vs. small or large.vs. large competitors. While participants indicated no.preference for the small or large shop when it was.competing against a competitor of similar size, the.small vs. large competitive context elicited a strong.preference for the small rather than large shop.
Question: The studies in the passage suggest that if customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, a likely result is that the large store would
Choices:
  A: receive more positive reviews from its customers.
  B: gain customers who perceive it as offering more choices than smaller shops.
  C: benefit from people's perception that its competition is now even greater.
  D: lose customers who would now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.
Response 0:
  The correct answer is D: lose customers who would now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.

The passage suggests that when consumers are exposed to a competitive narrative that emphasizes the small size of a local business, they are more likely to support the smaller competitor. In the field study conducted at an independent bookstore, shoppers who read the "large competitors" version of the in-store ad were more likely to make a purchase and spent more money at the store compared to those who read the "small competitors" or "no competition" versions. This suggests that framing the competitive game in this way can help a small establishment and spur consumers to make a purchase that supports the smaller competitor.

Therefore, if customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, it is likely that they would view the large store as a competitor to the smaller shops and choose to support the smaller competitor instead. This would result in the large store losing customers.

  The correct answer is D: lose customers who would now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.

The passage suggests that when consumers are aware of a large competitor, they are more likely to support the smaller brand. In the bookstore study, shoppers who read the "large competitors" version of the in-store ad were more likely to make a purchase and spent more money at the store compared to those who read the "small competitors" or "no competition" versions. This suggests that framing the competitive game and emphasizing a competitive narrative against a larger company can help a small establishment.

Therefore, if customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, it is likely that some customers would view the large store as a competitor to the smaller shops and choose to support the smaller shops instead. This would result in the large store losing customers.

This could result in a loss of customers for the large store.

Therefore, if customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, it is likely that they would view the large store as a competitor to the smaller shops and therefore be less likely to shop there. This would result in the large store losing customers to the smaller shops.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 56 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Lady Carlotta stepped out on to the platform of the small wayside station and took a turn or two up and down its uninteresting length, to kill time till the  train should be pleased to proceed on its way. Then,in the roadway beyond, she saw a horse struggling with a more than ample load, and a carter of the sort that seems to bear a sullen hatred against the animal that helps him to earn a living. Lady Carlotta promptly betook her to the roadway, and put rather a 10 different complexion on the struggle. Certain of her acquaintances were wont to give her plentiful admonition as to the undesirability of interfering on behalf of a distressed animal, such interference being "none of her business." Only once had she put the 1 doctrine of non-interference into practice, when one of its most eloquent exponents had been besieged for nearly three hours in a small and extremely uncomfortable may-tree by an angry boar-pig, while Lady Carlotta, on the other side of the fence, had20 proceeded with the water-colour sketch she was engaged on, and refused to interfere between the boar and his prisoner. It is to be feared that she lost the friendship of the ultimately rescued lady. On this occasion she merely lost the train, which gave way to 25 the first sign of impatience it had shown throughout the journey, and steamed off without her. She bore the desertion with philosophical indifference; her friends and relations were thoroughly well used to the fact of her luggage arriving without her.30 She wired a vague non-committal message to her destination to say that she was coming on "by another train." Before she had time to think what her next move might be she was confronted by an imposingly attired lady, who seemed to be taking a 35 prolonged mental inventory of her clothes and looks."You must be Miss Hope, the governess I've come to meet," said the apparition, in a tone that admitted of very little argument."Very well, if I must I must," said Lady Carlotta to 40 herself with dangerous meekness."I am Mrs. Quabarl," continued the lady; "and where, pray, is your luggage?""It's gone astray," said the alleged governess, falling in with the excellent rule of life that the absent 45 are always to blame; the luggage had, in point of fact, behaved with perfect correctitude. "I've just telegraphed about it," she added, with a nearer approach to truth."How provoking," said Mrs. Quabarl; "these 50 railway companies are so careless. However, my maid can lend you things for the night," and she led the way to her car.During the drive to the Quabarl mansion Lady Carlotta was impressively introduced to the 55 nature of the charge that had been thrust upon her; she learned that Claude and Wilfrid were delicate, sensitive young people, that Irene had the artistic temperament highly developed, and that Viola was something or other else of a mould equally60 commonplace among children of that class and type in the twentieth century."I wish them not only to be TAUGHT," said Mrs. Quabarl, "but INTERESTED in what they learn. In their history lessons, for instance, you must try to65 make them feel that they are being introduced to the life-stories of men and women who really lived, not merely committing a mass of names and dates to memory. French, of course, I shall expect you to talk at meal-times several days in the week."70 "I shall talk French four days of the week and Russian in the remaining three.""Russian? My dear Miss Hope, no one in the house speaks or understands Russian.""That will not embarrass me in the least," said 75 Lady Carlotta coldly.Mrs. Quabarl, to use a colloquial expression, was knocked off her perch. She was one of those imperfectly self-assured individuals who are magnificent and autocratic as long as they are not80 seriously opposed. The least show of unexpected resistance goes a long way towards rendering them cowed and apologetic. When the new governess failed to express wondering admiration of the large newly-purchased and expensive car, and lightly85 alluded to the superior advantages of one or two makes which had just been put on the market, the discomfiture of her patroness became almost abject. Her feelings were those which might have animated a general of ancient warfaring days, on beholding his 90 heaviest battle-elephant ignominiously driven off the field by slingers and javelin throwers.
Question: Which choice best summarizes the passage?
Choices:
  A: A woman weighs the positive and negative aspects of accepting a new job.
  B: A woman does not correct a stranger who mistakes her for someone else.
  C: A woman impersonates someone else to seek revenge on an acquaintance.
  D: A woman takes an immediate dislike to her new employer.
Response 0:
  The best summary of the passage is:

D: A woman takes an immediate dislike to her new employer.

The passage describes Lady Carlotta's encounter with Mrs. Quabarl, who has come to meet her at the train station to take her to the Quabarl mansion. Lady Carlotta, who has missed her train, is mistaken for the governess Mrs. Quabarl has come to meet, and she goes along with the charade. Mrs. Quabarl is portrayed as an imperious and self-assured woman who is used to getting her way, but Lady Carlotta's unconventional behavior and unexpected resistance throw Mrs. Quabarl off balance. The passage ends with Mrs. Quabarl feeling discomfited and apologetic. Therefore, option D best summarizes the passage.

  The correct answer is (D) A woman takes an immediate dislike to her new employer.

Lady Carlotta's sarcastic responses and lack of deference towards Mrs. Quabarl suggest that she takes an immediate dislike to her new employer. Therefore, option (D) is the best summary of the passage.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Texas gourd vines unfurl their large, flared.blossoms in the dim hours before sunrise. Until they.close at noon, their yellow petals and mild, squashy.aroma attract bees that gather nectar and shuttle.pollen from flower to flower. But “when you.advertise [to pollinators], you advertise in an.open communication network,” says chemical.ecologist Ian Baldwin of the Max Planck Institute for.Chemical Ecology in Germany. “You attract not just.the good guys, but you also attract the bad guys.” For.a Texas gourd plant, striped cucumber beetles are.among the very bad guys. They chew up pollen and.petals, defecate in the flowers and transmit the.dreaded bacterial wilt disease, an infection that can.reduce an entire plant to a heap of collapsed tissue in.mere days..In one recent study, Nina Theis and Lynn Adler.took on the specific problem of the Texas.gourd—how to attract enough pollinators but not.too many beetles. The Texas gourd vine’s main.pollinators are honey bees and specialized squash.bees, which respond to its floral scent. The aroma.includes 10 compounds, but the most.abundant—and the only one that lures squash bees.into traps—is 1,4-dimethoxybenzene..Intuition suggests that more of that aroma should.be even more appealing to bees. “We have this.assumption that a really fragrant flower is going to.attract a lot of pollinators,” says Theis, a chemical.ecologist at Elms College in Chicopee,.Massachusetts. But, she adds, that idea hasn’t really.been tested—and extra scent could well call in more.beetles, too. To find out, she and Adler planted 168 Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field and,.throughout the August flowering season, made half.the plants more fragrant by tucking.dimethoxybenzene-treated swabs deep inside their.flowers. Each treated flower emitted about 45 times.more fragrance than a normal one; the other half of.the plants got swabs without fragrance..The researchers also wanted to know whether.extra beetles would impose a double cost by both.damaging flowers and deterring bees, which might.not bother to visit (and pollinate) a flower laden with.other insects and their feces. So every half hour.throughout the experiments, the team plucked all the.beetles off of half the fragrance-enhanced flowers and.half the control flowers, allowing bees to respond to.the blossoms with and without interference by.beetles..Finally, they pollinated by hand half of the female.flowers in each of the four combinations of fragrance.and beetles. Hand-pollinated flowers should develop.into fruits with the maximum number of seeds,.providing a benchmark to see whether the.fragrance-related activities of bees and beetles.resulted in reduced pollination..“It was very labor intensive,” says Theis..“We would be out there at four in the morning, three.in the morning, to try and set up before these flowers.open.” As soon as they did, the team spent the next.several hours walking from flower to flower,.observing each for two-minute intervals “and writing.down everything we saw.”.What they saw was double the normal number of.beetles on fragrance-enhanced blossoms..Pollinators, to their surprise, did not prefer the.highly scented flowers. Squash bees were indifferent,.and honey bees visited enhanced flowers less often.than normal ones. Theis thinks the bees were.repelled not by the fragrance itself, but by the.abundance of beetles: The data showed that the more.beetles on a flower, the less likely a honey bee was to.visit it..That added up to less reproduction for.fragrance-enhanced flowers. Gourds that developed.from those blossoms weighed 9 percent less and had,.on average, 20 fewer seeds than those from normal.flowers. Hand pollination didn’t rescue the seed set,.indicating that beetles damaged flowers directly.—regardless of whether they also repelled.pollinators. (Hand pollination did rescue fruit.weight, a hard-to-interpret result that suggests that.lost bee visits did somehow harm fruit development.).The new results provide a reason that Texas gourd.plants never evolved to produce a stronger scent: “If.you really ramp up the odor, you don’t get more.pollinators, but you can really get ripped apart by.your enemies,” says Rob Raguso, a chemical ecologist.at Cornell University who was not involved in the.Texas gourd study.
Question: As presented in the passage, Theis and Adler’s research primarily relied on which type of evidence?
Choices:
  A: Direct observation
  B: Historical data
  C: Expert testimony
  D: Random sampling
Response 0:
  The correct answer is A: Direct observation.

The passage states that Theis and Adler conducted experiments by planting 168 Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field and manipulating the fragrance of some of the flowers. They also manually pollinated some of the flowers and observed the behavior of bees and beetles on the plants. The researchers collected data on the number of beetles and bees visiting the flowers, the amount of fragrance emitted, and the weight and seed count of the resulting gourds. Therefore, the primary type of evidence used in their research was direct observation.
Response 1:
  The answer is A: Direct observation.

Theis and Adler's research primarily relied on direct observation of the behavior of bees and beetles on Texas gourd plants. They conducted experiments in an Iowa field, planting 168 Texas gourd vines and manipulating the fragrance of some of the flowers to attract more pollinators. They then observed the behavior of bees and beetles on the flowers, both with and without fragrance enhancement, and recorded their findings. They also manually pollinated some of the flowers to establish a baseline for comparison. The researchers spent several hours walking from flower to flower, observing each for two-minute intervals and writing down everything they saw. This direct observation of the behavior of pollinators and pests on the manipulated flowers was the primary method of data collection for their study.
Response 2:
  The correct answer is A: Direct observation.

The passage states that Theis and Adler conducted experiments by planting 168 Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field and manipulating the fragrance of half of the plants. They also manually pollinated some of the flowers to control for the effects of beetles and bees. The researchers spent several hours walking from flower to flower, observing each for two-minute intervals and writing down everything they saw. They collected data on the number of beetles and bees visiting each flower, as well as the weight and seed number of the resulting gourds.

Therefore, the primary type of evidence used in this study was direct observation, as the researchers directly observed and recorded the behavior of bees, beetles, and the effects on the gourds.
Response 3:
  Theis and Adler's research primarily relied on direct observation. They conducted experiments by planting 168 Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field, and throughout the August flowering season, they made half the plants more fragrant by tucking dimethoxybenzene-treated swabs deep inside their flowers. They also plucked beetles off of half the fragrance-enhanced flowers and half the control flowers every half hour, and they pollinated by hand half of the female flowers in each of the four combinations of fragrance and beetles. They observed each flower for two-minute intervals and wrote down everything they saw. Therefore, direct observation was the primary type of evidence used in their research.

Therefore, the primary type of evidence used in Theis and Adler's research was direct observation, as they directly observed and recorded the behavior of the pollinators and the effects of fragrance manipulation on fruit development.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 58 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Unlike the gold which needed nothing, and must be worshipped in close-locked solitude - which was hidden away from the daylight, was deaf to the song  of birds, and started to no human tones-Eppie was a 5 creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires, seeking and loving sunshine, and living sounds, and living movements; making trial of everything, with trust in new joy, and stirring the human kindness in all eyes that looked on her. The gold had kept his10 thoughts in an ever-repeated circle, leading to nothing beyond itself; but Eppie was an object compacted of changes and hopes that forced his thoughts onward, and carried them far away from their old eager pacing towards the same blank15 limit-carried them away to the new things that would come with the coming years, when Eppie would have learned to understand how her father Silas cared for her; and made him look for images of that time in the ties and charities that bound together 20 the families of his neighbors. The gold had asked that he should sit weaving longer and longer, deafened and blinded more and more to all things except the monotony of his loom and the repetition of his web; but Eppie called him away from his weaving, and25 made him think all its pauses a holiday, reawakening his senses with her fresh life, even to the old winter-flies that came crawling forth in the early spring sunshine, and warming him into joy because she had joy.30 And when the sunshine grew strong and lasting, so that the buttercups were thick in the meadows, Silas might be seen in the sunny mid-day, or in the late afternoon when the shadows were lengthening under the hedgerows, strolling out with uncovered35 head to carry Eppie beyond the Stone-pits to where the flowers grew, till they reached some favorite bank where he could sit down, while Eppie toddled to pluck the flowers, and make remarks to the winged things that murmured happily above the bright40 petals, calling "Dad-dad's" attention continually by bringing him the flowers. Then she would turn her ear to some sudden bird-note, and Silas learned to please her by making signs of hushed stillness, that they might listen for the note to come again: so that45 when it came, she set up her small back and laughed with gurgling triumph. Sitting on the banks in this way, Silas began to look for the once familiar herbs again; and as the leaves, with their unchanged outline and markings, lay on his palm, there was a sense of 50 crowding remembrances from which he turned away timidly, taking refuge in Eppie's little world, that lay lightly on his enfeebled spirit. As the child's mind was growing into knowledge, his mind was growing into memory: as her lifeunfolded, his soul, long stupefied in a cold narrow prison, was unfolding too, and trembling gradually into full consciousness.It was an influence which must gather force with every new year: the tones that stirred Silas' heart60 grew articulate, and called for more distinct answers; shapes and sounds grew clearer for Eppie's eyes and ears, and there was more that "Dad-dad" was imperatively required to notice and account for. Also, by the time Eppie was three years old, she65 developed a fine capacity for mischief, and for devising ingenious ways of being troublesome, which found much exercise, not only for Silas' patience, but for his watchfulness and penetration. Sorely was poor Silas puzzled on such occasions by the incompatible 70 demands of love.
Question: In describing the relationship between Eppie and Silas, the narrator draws a connection between Eppie's
Choices:
  A: physical vulnerability and Silas's emotional fragility.
  B: expanding awareness and Silas's increasing engagement with life.
  C: boundless energy and Silas's insatiable desire for wealth.
  D: physical growth and Silas's painful perception of his own mortality.
Response 0:
  Answer: B

The passage describes Eppie as a "creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires" who is constantly seeking new experiences and making Silas aware of the world around him. The narrator notes that Eppie's "fresh life" and "joy" have a positive impact on Silas, who becomes more engaged with life and aware of the world around him as he spends time with her. The passage also states that as Eppie grows and develops, Silas's mind is "growing into memory" and his soul is "unfolding too, and trembling gradually into full consciousness." Therefore, choice B is the best answer.
Response 1:
  Answer: B

The passage suggests that Eppie's "ever-growing desires" and "fresh life" have a positive impact on Silas, who has been "stupefied in a cold narrow prison" and is now "unfolding too, and trembling gradually into full consciousness." The connection drawn between Eppie and Silas is one of expanding awareness and increasing engagement with life, as Silas becomes more aware of the world around him through his interactions with Eppie. This is highlighted in the passage when it states that "Eppie was an object compacted of changes and hopes that forced his thoughts onward, and carried them far away from their old eager pacing towards the same blank limit." Therefore, option B is the best answer.

However, as he spends time with Eppie, he begins to awaken from his stupor and engage with the world around him. The narrator notes that Eppie's mind is growing into knowledge, while Silas's mind is growing into memory, and that as her life unfolds, his soul is unfolding too.

This is in contrast to option A, which suggests a connection between Eppie's physical vulnerability and Silas's emotional fragility, and option C, which suggests a connection between Eppie's boundless energy and Silas's insatiable desire for wealth. Option D, which suggests a connection between Eppie's physical growth and Silas's painful perception of his own mortality, is not supported by the text.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 59 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Anyone watching the autumn sky knows that migrating birds fly in a $\mathrm{V}$ formation, but scientists have long debated why. A new study of ibises finds  that these big-winged birds carefully position theirwingtips and sync their flapping, presumably to catch the preceding bird's updraft-and save energy during flight.There are two reasons birds might fly in a V formation: It may make flight easier, or they're  simply following the leader. Squadrons of planes can save fuel by flying in a $\mathrm{V}$ formation, and many scientists suspect that migrating birds do the same. Models that treated flapping birds like fixed-wing airplanes estimate that they save energy by draftingoff each other, but currents created by airplanes are far more stable than the oscillating eddies coming off of a bird. "Air gets pretty unpredictable behind a flapping wing," says James Usherwood, a locomotor biomechanist at the Royal Veterinary College at theUniversity of London in Hatfield, where the research took place.The study, published in Nature, took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) to Europe.Scientists used a microlight plane to show hand-raised birds their ancestral migration route from Austria to Italy. A flock of 14 juveniles carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. The device's GPS determined each bird's flight 30 position to within $30 \mathrm{~cm}$, and an accelerometer showed the timing of the wing flaps.Just as aerodynamic estimates would predict, the birds positioned themselves to fly just behind and to the side of the bird in front, timing their wing beats35 to catch the uplifting eddies. When a bird flew directly behind another, the timing of the flapping reversed so that it could minimize the effects of the downdraft coming off the back of the bird's body. "We didn't think this was possible," Usherwood 40 says, considering that the feat requires careful flight and incredible awareness of one's neighbors. "Perhaps these big V formation birds can be thought of quite like an airplane with wings that go up and down." 45 The findings likely apply to other long-winged birds, such as pelicans, storks, and geese, Usherwood says. Smaller birds create more complex wakes that would make drafting too difficult. The researchers did not attempt to calculate the bird's energy savings50 because the necessary physiological measurements would be too invasive for an endangered species. Previous studies estimate that birds can use 20 percent to  percent less energy while flying in a $\mathrm{V}$.55 "From a behavioral perspective it's really a breakthrough," says David Lentink, a mechanical engineer at Stanford University in Palo Alto, California, who was not involved in the work. "Showing that birds care about syncing their wing 60 beats is definitely an important insight that we didn't have before."Scientists do not know how the birds find that aerodynamic sweet spot, but they suspect that the animals align themselves either by sight or65 by sensing air currents through their feathers.Alternatively, they may move around until they find the location with the least resistance. In future studies, the researchers will switch to more common birds, such as pigeons or geese. They plan to70 investigate how the animals decide who sets the course and the pace, and whether a mistake made by the leader can ripple through the rest of the flock to cause traffic jams."It's a pretty impressive piece of work as it is, but 75 it does suggest that there's a lot more to learn," says Ty Hedrick, a biologist at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, who studies flight aerodynamics in birds and insects. However they do it, he says, "birds are awfully good hang-glider 80 pilots."
Question: What can reasonably be inferred about the reason Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study?
Choices:
  A: The ibises were well acquainted with their migration route.
  B: Usherwood knew the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration.
  C: The ibises have a body design that is similar to that of a modern airplane.
  D: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.
Response 0:
  The correct answer is (D) The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.

The passage states that the study took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises to Europe, and that the birds carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. This suggests that the ibises were already being tracked and monitored as part of the reintroduction project, making them a convenient and accessible subject for Usherwood's study on bird migration.

The other options are not supported by the passage. There is no mention of the ibises being well acquainted with their migration route (A), or of Usherwood knowing that the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration (B). Additionally, the passage does not suggest that the ibises have a body design similar to that of a modern airplane (C).
Response 1:
  Based on the information provided in the passage, it can be inferred that Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study because they were easily accessible for him and his team to track and observe. The passage states that the study took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises to Europe, and that the birds carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. This suggests that Usherwood chose the ibises because they were already being monitored and tracked as part of the reintroduction project, making it easier for him to collect data on their flight behavior. Therefore, the best answer is (D) The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.

It's likely that Usherwood chose the ibises as the subjects of his study because they were already being tracked and monitored as part of the reintroduction project, making it easier for him and his team to observe and collect data on their flight patterns.

There is no mention of the ibises being well acquainted with their migration route (A), or of Usherwood knowing that the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration (B). The ibises' body design is not mentioned as being similar to that of a modern airplane (C).

This suggests that the ibises were already being raised and trained for migration, and that Usherwood and his team were able to easily access and observe them during their migration.

Response 7:
  The correct answer is (D) The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.

The article states that the study took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises to Europe. The researchers used a microlight plane to show hand-raised birds their ancestral migration route from Austria to Italy. This suggests that the ibises were already being raised and trained for migration, making them easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.

There is no mention in the article of the ibises being well acquainted with their migration route (A), carrying data loggers during migration (B), or having a body design similar to that of a modern airplane (C).
Response 8:
  The correct answer is D: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.

The passage states that the study took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises to Europe, and that the birds were hand-raised and carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. This suggests that the ibises were already being monitored and tracked as part of the reintroduction project, making them an accessible and convenient choice for Usherwood's study.

There is no evidence in the passage to suggest that the ibises were well acquainted with their migration route (A), familiar with carrying data loggers during migration (B), or have a body design similar to that of a modern airplane (C).

  The correct answer is D: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.

The passage states that the study took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises to Europe, and that the birds carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. The fact that the ibises were hand-raised and familiar with their migration route may have also made them easier to work with, but this is not the primary reason why Usherwood chose them as his subjects.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 60 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Even then my only friends were made of paper and ink. At school I had learned to read and write long before the other children. Where my school  friends saw notches of ink on incomprehensiblepages, I saw light, streets, and people. Words and the mystery of their hidden science fascinated me, and I saw in them a key with which I could unlock a boundless world, a safe haven from that home, those streets, and those troubled days in which even Icould sense that only a limited fortune awaited me. My father didn't like to see books in the house. There was something about them-apart from the letters he could not decipher-that offended him. He used to tell me that as soon as I was ten he would 15 send me off to work and that I'd better get rid of all my scatterbrained ideas if I didn't want to end up a loser, a nobody. I used to hide my books under the mattress and wait for him to go out or fall asleep so that I could read. Once he caught me reading at night20 and flew into a rage. He tore the book from my hands and flung it out of the window."If I catch you wasting electricity again, reading all this nonsense, you'll be sorry."My father was not a miser and, despite the 25 hardships we suffered, whenever he could he gave me a few coins so that I could buy myself some treats like the other children. He was convinced that I spent them on licorice sticks, sunflower seeds, or sweets, but I would keep them in a coffee tin under the bed, 30 and when I'd collected four or five reales I'd secretly rush out to buy myself a book.My favorite place in the whole city was the Sempere \& Sons bookshop on Calle Santa Ana. It smelled of old paper and dust and it was my35 sanctuary, my refuge. The bookseller would let me sit on a chair in a corner and read any book I liked to my heart's content. He hardly ever allowed me to pay for the books he placed in my hands, but when he wasn't looking I'd leave the coins I'd managed to 40 collect on the counter before I left. It was only small change-if I'd had to buy a book with that pittance, I would probably have been able to afford only a booklet of cigarette papers. When it was time for me to leave, I would do so dragging my feet, a weight on $45 \mathrm{my}$ soul. If it had been up to me, I would have stayed there forever.One Christmas Sempere gave me the best gift I have ever received. It was an old volume, read and experienced to the full.50 "Great Expectations, by Charles Dickens," I read on the cover.I was aware that Sempere knew a few authors who frequented his establishment and, judging by the care with which he handled the volume, I thought 55 perhaps this Mr. Dickens was one of them."A friend of yours?""A lifelong friend. And from now on, he's your friend too." That afternoon I took my new friend home, 60 hidden under my clothes so that my father wouldn't see it. It was a rainy winter, with days as gray as lead, and I read Great Expectations about nine times, partly because I had no other book at hand, partly because I did not think there could be a better one in 65 the whole world and I was beginning to suspect that Mr. Dickens had written it just for me. Soon I was convinced that I didn't want to do anything else in life but learn to do what Mr. Dickens had done.
Question: Over the course of the passage, the main focus shifts from a
Choices:
  A: general discussion of the narrator's love of reading to a portrayal of an influential incident.
  B: depiction of the narrator's father to an examination of an author with whom the narrator becomes enchanted.
  C: symbolic representation of a skill the narrator possesses to an example of its application.
  D: tale about the hardships of the narrator's childhood to an analysis of the effects of those hardships.
Response 0:
  The correct answer is A: general discussion of the narrator's love of reading to a portrayal of an influential incident.

The passage begins by discussing the narrator's love of reading and how it was a source of comfort and escape for them. It then shifts to a specific incident where the narrator's father, who did not approve of reading, discovers the narrator reading at night and tears the book from their hands. This incident is a turning point in the passage and marks a shift in the narrator's relationship with reading.

Option B is incorrect because while the passage does mention the narrator's father, it does not focus on him or his character. Option C is also incorrect because while the passage mentions the narrator's skill at reading, it does not symbolically represent it or provide an example of its application. Option D is incorrect because while the passage does mention the hardships of the narrator's childhood, it does not analyze their effects.

Therefore, the main focus of the passage shifts from a general discussion of the narrator's love of reading to a portrayal of an influential incident, specifically the gift of Great Expectations from Sempere and the narrator's subsequent desire to become a writer.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 61 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: Which of the following is equivalent to $3(x+5)-6$ ?
Choices:
  A: $3 x-3$
  B: $3 x-1$
  C: $3 x+9$
  D: $15 x-6$
Response 0:
  Knowledge:

* The distributive property of multiplication over addition: $a(b+c) = ab + ac$
* The fact that $3(x+5) = 3x + 3(5) = 3x + 15$

Thought:

Let's evaluate the given expression:

$3(x+5) - 6$

= $3x + 3(5) - 6$ (using the distributive property)

= $3x + 15 - 6$

= $3x + 9$

So, the equivalent expression is:

$3(x+5) - 6$ = $3x + 9$

Therefore, the correct answer is:

C: $3x + 9$

Criticism:

It's important to note that the distributive property only works when the multiplication is performed before the addition. In this case, the expression $3(x+5) - 6$ can be misleading, as the subtraction is performed before the multiplication. However, we can still use the distributive property by evaluating the expression as $3(x+5) = 3x + 3(5) = 3x + 15$, and then subtracting 6.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
  Knowledge:

* The distributive property of multiplication over addition: $a(b+c) = ab + ac$
* The fact that $3(x+5) = 3x + 3(5) = 3x + 15$

Thought:

* Let's evaluate the given expression: $3(x+5) - 6$
* Using the distributive property, we can rewrite it as: $3x + 3(5) - 6$
* Simplifying, we get: $3x + 15 - 6$
* Now, we can simplify further: $3x + 9$

Criticism:

* You have correctly applied the distributive property, but you forgot to simplify the expression further.
* The correct answer is C: $3x + 9$.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 2:
  Knowledge:

* The distributive property states that $a(b+c) = ab + ac$
* The associative property states that $(a+b) + c = a + (b+c)$

Thought:

Let's expand the expression $3(x+5)-6$ using the distributive property:

$3(x+5) = 3x + 3(5) = 3x + 15$

Now, let's simplify:

$3x + 15 - 6 = 3x + 9$

So, the equivalent expression is:

$3(x+5) - 6 = 3x + 9$

Criticism:

It's important to note that the distributive property only works when the term being distributed is a constant, not a variable. In this case, $3$ is a constant, so we can use the distributive property to expand $3(x+5)$. However, we cannot distribute the $3$ to the $x$ term, because $x$ is a variable. Therefore, the correct answer is C: $3x+9$.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 62 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: $$\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$$Which of the following represents all the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation above?
Choices:
  A: 0 and 2
  B: 0 and 4
  C: -4 and 4
  D: 4
Response 0:
  Knowledge:

* The equation $\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified by multiplying both sides by $x-3$ to get $x = 2x - 6$.
* Solving for $x$, we get $x = 2$ or $x = 0$.

Thought:

* Let's consider each choice:
	+ A: 0 and 2 are both solutions to the equation, so this choice is correct.
	+ B: 0 and 4 are not both solutions to the equation, since 0 is not a solution.
	+ C: -4 and 4 are not both solutions to the equation, since -4 is not a solution.
	+ D: 4 is a solution to the equation, but 0 is not, so this choice is incorrect.

Action: Answer("A")
Response 1:
  Knowledge:

The equation can be simplified by canceling out the common factor of $x$ in the numerator and denominator:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2} \Rightarrow x - 3 = 2$$

Solving for $x$, we get:

$$x = 5$$

So, the only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 5$.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 2:
  Knowledge:

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified by multiplying both sides by $x-3$ to get:

$$x = 2x - 6$$

Solving for $x$, we get:

$$x = 6$$

Therefore, the only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $6$.

Thought:

Since the equation is a statement of equality, we can use the extrema of the functions involved to find the possible values of $x$.

The function $\frac{x}{x-3}$ has a minimum value of $0$ when $x=3$ and a maximum value of $+\infty$ as $x\to\infty$.

The function $\frac{2x}{2}$ has a minimum value of $0$ when $x=0$ and a maximum value of $+\infty$ as $x\to\infty$.

Since the two functions have the same minimum value of $0$, we can conclude that the only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $0$.

However, this is not one of the options given.

Criticism:

The reasoning above is flawed because it only considers the extrema of the functions involved and not the actual values that satisfy the equation.

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}$ can be solved to find the only possible value of $x$, which is $6$.

Therefore, the correct answer is option D: $4$.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 3:
  Knowledge:

The equation is a simplification of the expression:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$$

We can simplify the left-hand side of the equation by canceling out the $x$ term:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2}{2-3}$$

Now, we can see that the expression is equal to 1, so the equation becomes:

$$1 = \frac{2}{2-3}$$

We can simplify further by canceling out the 2 on both sides:

$$1 = \frac{1}{2-3}$$

Now, we can see that the expression is equal to 1, so the equation becomes:

$$1 = 1$$

This means that any value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is also equal to 1.

Thought:

Since the equation is trivially true for any value of $x$, all values of $x$ satisfy the equation.

Criticism:

While it's true that the equation is trivially true for any value of $x$, it's important to note that the question is asking for the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation. In this case, the only value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is 1.

Action: Answer("A")
Response 4:
  Knowledge:

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified by multiplying both sides by $x-3$ to get:

$$x = 2x - 6$$

Solving for $x$, we get:

$$x = 2x - 6$$

$$x - 2x = -6$$

$$-x = -6$$

Therefore, we have $x = 0$ or $x = 6$.

Thought:

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}$ is saying that the ratio of $x$ to $x-3$ is equal to the ratio of $2x$ to $2$. This means that $x-3$ must be a factor of $2x$. Therefore, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $0$ and $6$, since $0-3 = 0$ and $6-3 = 3$ are both factors of $2$.

Criticism:

Your answer is correct, but your explanation could be improved. You should have mentioned that the equation can be simplified by multiplying both sides by $x-3$, and that the equation is saying that $x-3$ is a factor of $2x$.

Action: Answer("A")
Response 5:
  Knowledge:

* The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified by multiplying both sides by $x-3$ to get $\frac{x(x-3)}{(x-3)^2} = \frac{2x}{2}$.
* This equation can be factored as $\frac{x(x-3)}{(x-3)^2} = \frac{2x}{2} \iff x(x-3) = 2(x-3)^2$.
* Solving for $x$, we get $x^2 - 6x + 3 = 0$.
* The discriminant of this quadratic equation is $b^2 - 4ac = (-6)^2 - 4(1)(3) = 36 - 12 = 24$.
* Since the discriminant is positive, the equation has two distinct solutions.

Thought:

* Let's solve the quadratic equation $x^2 - 6x + 3 = 0$.
* We can factor it as $(x - 3)(x - 1) = 0$.
* So, we have $x - 3 = 0$ or $x - 1 = 0$.
* Solving for $x$, we get $x = 3$ or $x = 1$.
* Since $x = 1$ is not a valid solution, the only solution is $x = 3$.

Criticism:

* You are correct that the equation $x^2 - 6x + 3 = 0$ has two distinct solutions.
* However, you should have noticed that the equation has no real solutions.
* The solutions are $x = 3 \pm \sqrt{3}i$, which are complex numbers.
* So, the correct answer is $D: 4$, since there are no real solutions to the equation.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 6:
  Knowledge:

The equation can be simplified by canceling out the $x$ term:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2} \Rightarrow \frac{x-3}{2} = x \Rightarrow x-3 = 2x \Rightarrow x = 3$$

So, the only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 3$.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 7:
  Knowledge:

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified by multiplying both sides by $x-3$ to get:

$$\frac{x^2 - 3x}{x-3} = \frac{2x^2}{2}$$

Now, we can see that the left-hand side is a constant times the original equation, so the solutions to the equation are the same as the solutions to the original equation.

Let's factor the left-hand side:

$$\frac{x^2 - 3x}{x-3} = \frac{(x - 1)(x + 3)}{(x-3)(x-3)} = \frac{x - 1}{x-3} \cdot \frac{x + 3}{x-3}$$

We can see that the product of the two fractions is equal to 1, so we can set each factor equal to 1 separately:

$$\frac{x - 1}{x-3} = 1 \Rightarrow x - 1 = x-3 \Rightarrow x = 2$$

$$\frac{x + 3}{x-3} = 1 \Rightarrow x + 3 = x-3 \Rightarrow x = -4$$

So, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $x = 2$ and $x = -4$.

Action: Answer("B")
Response 8:
  Knowledge:

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$ can be simplified by multiplying both sides by $x-3$ to get:

$$x = 2x - 6$$

Solving for $x$, we get:

$$x = 2x - 6$$

$$x - 2x = -6$$

$$-x = -6$$

Therefore, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $x = 0$ and $x = -6$.

Thought:

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$ is a proportion, and it can be solved by cross-multiplying and simplifying. The equation $x = 2x - 6$ can be factored to $x - 2x = -6$, which simplifies to $-x = -6$. Therefore, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $x = 0$ and $x = -6$.

Criticism:

The equation $x = 2x - 6$ can also be factored as $x(1 - 2) = -6$, which gives $x = 0$ or $x = -3$. However, $x = -3$ does not satisfy the original equation, so the only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 0$.

Action: Answer("A")
Response 9:
  Knowledge:

The equation is a proportion, and it can be written as:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$$

We can cross-multiply and simplify to get:

$$x^2 - 3x = 4$$

This is a quadratic equation, and it factors as:

$$(x - 1)(x + 3) = 0$$

So, we have two possible cases:

1. $x - 1 = 0 \Rightarrow x = 1$
2. $x + 3 = 0 \Rightarrow x = -3$

Therefore, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $x = 1$ and $x = -3$.

Thought:

A: 0 and 2

$0$ is not a solution to the equation, and $2$ is not a solution either. So, this choice is incorrect.

B: 0 and 4

$0$ is not a solution to the equation, and $4$ is not a solution either. So, this choice is incorrect.

C: -4 and 4

$-4$ is a solution to the equation, and $4$ is not a solution. So, this choice is incorrect.

D: 4

$4$ is not a solution to the equation. So, this choice is incorrect.

Action: Answer("B")

The correct answer is B: 0 and 4.

Although none of the choices contain all the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, choice B contains one of the solutions, which is $0$. The other solution, $-3$, is not listed in any of the choices. Therefore, choice B is the best answer.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 63 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: $$\begin{aligned}1 \text { decagram } & =10 \text { grams } \\1,000 \text { milligrams } & =1 \text { gram }\end{aligned}$$A hospital stores one type of medicine in 2-decagram containers. Based on the information given in the box above, how many 1-milligram doses are there in one 2-decagram container?
Choices:
  A: $\quad 0.002$
  B: $\quad 200$
  C: $\quad 2,000$
  D: 20,000
Response 0:
  To find the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container, we need to convert the amount of medicine in the container from decagrams to milligrams.

We know that 1 decagram = 10 grams, and 1 gram = 1,000 milligrams. Therefore, we can convert 2 decagrams to milligrams as follows:

2 decagrams = 2 x 10 grams = 20 grams
20 grams = 20,000 milligrams

So, there are 20,000 milligrams in one 2-decagram container.

Now, we can compare the answer with the given choices:

A: 0.002 milligrams (This is not equal to 20,000 milligrams, so this choice is incorrect.)
B: 200 milligrams (This is not equal to 20,000 milligrams, so this choice is incorrect.)
C: 2,000 milligrams (This is not equal to 20,000 milligrams, so this choice is incorrect.)
D: 20,000 milligrams (This is equal to the amount of medicine in the container, so this choice is correct.)

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) 20,000 milligrams.
Response 1:
  Knowledge:

* 1 decagram (dag) is equal to 10 grams (g)
* 1 gram (g) is equal to 1,000 milligrams (mg)

Thought:

* We know that the hospital stores the medicine in 2-decagram containers.
* We can convert 2 decagrams to grams by multiplying by 10: 2 dag = 2 x 10 g = 20 g
* We can convert 20 grams to milligrams by multiplying by 1,000: 20 g = 20 x 1,000 mg = 20,000 mg

 Action: Answer("D")

Criticism:

* You are correct that there are 20,000 milligrams in 2 decagrams.
* However, the question asks for the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container.
* To find this, we need to divide the number of milligrams by 1,000: 20,000 mg ÷ 1,000 = 20 doses.
* Therefore, the correct answer is C: 2,000.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 2:
  Knowledge:

* 1 decagram (dag) = 10 grams (g)
* 1 gram (g) = 1000 milligrams (mg)

Thought:

1. We know that 1 decagram (dag) = 10 grams (g).
2. We also know that 1 gram (g) = 1000 milligrams (mg).
3. So, we can convert 2 decagrams (dag) to grams as follows:
2 dag = 2 x 10 g = 20 g
4. Now, we can convert 20 grams to milligrams as follows:
20 g = 20 x 1000 mg = 20,000 mg

Therefore, there are 20,000 milligrams in one 2-decagram container.

2 decagrams = 2 x 10 grams = 20 grams

Now, we can convert 20 grams to milligrams:

20 grams = 20 x 1000 milligrams = 20,000 milligrams

Therefore, there are 20,000 milligrams in one 2-decagram container.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 64 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members for an upcoming project. The staff members will be made up of junior directors, who will be paid $\$ 640$ per week, and senior directors, who will be paid $\$ 880$ per week. Her budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$ 9,700$ per week. She must hire at least 3 junior directors and at least 1 senior director. Which of the following systems of inequalities represents the conditions described if $x$ is the number of junior directors and $y$ is the number of senior directors?
Choices:
  A: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$
  B: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$
  C: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$
  D: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$
Response 0:
  Let's first analyze the problem:

* Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members, so the total number of staff members must be greater than or equal to 10.
* The budget for paying the staff members is no more than $9,700$ per week.
* She must hire at least 3 junior directors, so the number of junior directors must be greater than or equal to 3.
* She must hire at least 1 senior director, so the number of senior directors must be greater than or equal to 1.

Now, let's evaluate the given choices:

A: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$

This choice satisfies all the conditions:

* $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ ensures that the total salary paid to the staff members does not exceed the budget.
* $x+y \leq 10$ ensures that the total number of staff members does not exceed 10.
* $x \geq 3$ ensures that at least 3 junior directors are hired.
* $y \geq 1$ ensures that at least 1 senior director is hired.

B: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$

This choice does not satisfy the condition $x+y \leq 10$, as it requires the total number of staff members to be greater than or equal to 10.

C: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$

This choice does not satisfy the condition $x \geq 3$, as it requires the number of junior directors to be less than or equal to 3.

D: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$

This choice does not satisfy the condition $y \geq 1$, as it requires the number of senior directors to be less than or equal to 1.

Therefore, the correct answer is A: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$.

The second inequality represents the condition that the number of staff members should not exceed 10. The third and fourth inequalities represent the conditions that at least 3 junior directors and at least 1 senior director should be hired.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 65 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: In air, the speed of sound $S$, in meters per second, is a linear function of the air temperature $T$, in degrees Celsius, and is given by $S(T)=0.6 T+331.4$. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the number 331.4 in this context?
Choices:
  A: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
  B: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
  C: The increase in the speed of sound, in meters per second, that corresponds to an increase of $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
  D: The increase in the speed of sound, in meters per second, that corresponds to an increase of $0.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
Response 0:
  The best interpretation of the number 331.4 in the context of the speed of sound in air is:

A: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

This is because the equation $S(T) = 0.6T + 331.4$ indicates that the speed of sound increases linearly with temperature, and 331.4 is the constant term in the equation. Therefore, 331.4 represents the speed of sound at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

Here's how the other options relate to the question:

B: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is not directly related to the number 331.4. This option would require us to plug in $T = 0.6$ into the equation $S(T) = 0.6T + 331.4$, which gives $S = 0.6(0.6) + 331.4 = 337.4$ meters per second.

C: The increase in the speed of sound, in meters per second, that corresponds to an increase of $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is not directly related to the number 331.4. To find this quantity, we would need to calculate the derivative of $S(T)$ with respect to $T$, which is $0.6$. Then, we can plug in $T = 1$ into the equation $S(T) = 0.6T + 331.4$ to find the increase in the speed of sound for a $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ increase: $S(1) - S(0) = 0.6(1) + 331.4 - 331.4 = 0.6$.

D: The increase in the speed of sound, in meters per second, that corresponds to an increase of $0.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is not directly related to the number 331.4. This option would require us to calculate the derivative of $S(T)$ with respect to $T$, which is $0.6$, and then plug in $T = 0.6$ into the equation $S(T) = 0.6T + 331.4$ to find the increase in the speed of sound for a $0.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ increase: $S(0.6) - S(0) = 0.6(0.6) + 331.4 - 331.4 = 0.36$.

Therefore, the best answer is option A.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 66 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: A line in the $x y$-plane passes through the origin and has a slope of $\frac{1}{7}$. Which of the following points lies on the line?
Choices:
  A: $(0,7)$
  B: $(1,7)$
  C: $(7,7)$
  D: $(14,2)$
Response 0:
  Knowledge:

* The slope-intercept form of a linear equation is $y = mx + b$, where $m$ is the slope and $b$ is the y-intercept.
* If the slope is positive, the line slopes upward from left to right, and if the slope is negative, the line slopes downward from left to right.
* If the slope is $\frac{1}{7}$, then the line passes through the origin and has a positive slope.

Thought:

* The line passes through the origin, so it must have the form $y = \frac{1}{7}x + b$, where $b$ is the y-intercept.
* Since the slope is positive, the line slopes upward from left to right, so the y-intercept must be positive.
* The only choice with a positive y-intercept is A: $(0,7)$.

Criticism:

* You are correct that the line passes through the origin and has a positive slope, but you didn't consider the other choices carefully enough.
* Choice B: $(1,7)$ also has a positive y-intercept and could potentially be on the line.
* Choice C: $(7,7)$ has a negative y-intercept, so it cannot be on the line.
* Choice D: $(14,2)$ has a positive y-intercept, but it is not on the line because it has a different slope.

Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
  Knowledge:

* The equation of a line in the $x y$-plane can be written as $y = mx + b$, where $m$ is the slope and $b$ is the y-intercept.
* If the slope of a line is $\frac{1}{7}$, then the line passes through the origin (since the y-intercept is $0$).
* The point $(0,7)$ has a y-coordinate of $7$, which is not equal to $0$, so it does not lie on the line.
* The point $(1,7)$ has a y-coordinate of $7$, which is equal to the slope of the line multiplied by the x-coordinate ($1 \times \frac{1}{7} = 7$), so it does lie on the line.
* The point $(7,7)$ has a y-coordinate of $7$, which is not equal to the slope of the line multiplied by the x-coordinate ($7 \times \frac{1}{7} = 1$), so it does not lie on the line.
* The point $(14,2)$ has a y-coordinate of $2$, which is not equal to the slope of the line multiplied by the x-coordinate ($14 \times \frac{1}{7} = 2$), so it does not lie on the line.

Thought:

* The line passes through the origin, so the y-coordinate of any point on the line will be equal to the slope of the line multiplied by the x-coordinate.
* The point $(1,7)$ has a y-coordinate of $7$, which is equal to the slope of the line multiplied by the x-coordinate ($1 \times \frac{1}{7} = 7$), so it must be the point that lies on the line.

Response 3:
  Knowledge:

* The equation of a line in the $x y$-plane can be written in the slope-intercept form, which is $y = mx + b$, where $m$ is the slope and $b$ is the y-intercept.
* In this case, the slope of the line is given as $\frac{1}{7}$, so we can start by writing the equation of the line as $y = \frac{1}{7}x + b$.
* To find the y-intercept $b$, we can use the fact that the line passes through the origin, which means that $x = 0$ and $y = 0$. Substituting these values into the equation, we get $0 = \frac{1}{7}(0) + b$, which simplifies to $b = 0$.
* Therefore, the equation of the line becomes $y = \frac{1}{7}x$.

Thought:

* Now that we have the equation of the line, we can substitute the coordinates of each choice into the equation to see which one lies on the line.
* A: $(0,7)$: Substituting $x = 0$ and $y = 7$ into the equation, we get $7 = \frac{1}{7}(0) + 0$, which is not true. So, choice A does not lie on the line.
* B: $(1,7)$: Substituting $x = 1$ and $y = 7$ into the equation, we get $7 = \frac{1}{7}(1) + 0$, which is true. So, choice B lies on the line.
* C: $(7,7)$: Substituting $x = 7$ and $y = 7$ into the equation, we get $7 = \frac{1}{7}(7) + 0$, which is true. So, choice C lies on the line.
* D: $(14,2)$: Substituting $x = 14$ and $y = 2$ into the equation, we get $2 = \frac{1}{7}(14) + 0$, which is not true. So, choice D does not lie on the line.

Criticism:

* You have correctly identified the line as $y = \frac{1}{7}x$ and have correctly determined which choices lie on the line.
* However, you should be careful to note that the line also passes through the origin, which means that the y-intercept is actually $b = 0$, not $b = 7$.
* This does not affect the correct answer, but it is important to be precise in your calculations and explanations.

Response 7:
  Knowledge:

* The equation of a line in the $x y$-plane that passes through the origin can be written in the slope-intercept form, where the slope is denoted by $m$ and the y-intercept is denoted by $b$. The equation is: $y = mx + b$.
* In this case, the slope of the line is given as $\frac{1}{7}$, so we can write the equation as: $y = \frac{1}{7}x + b$.
* To find the point that lies on the line, we need to solve for $b$.

Thought:

* Let's solve for $b$ by substituting $x = 0$ into the equation: $y = \frac{1}{7}x + b$.
* When $x = 0$, $y = b$, so we have: $b = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 0 + b = b$.
* Therefore, $b = 0$.
* Now we can write the equation of the line as: $y = \frac{1}{7}x$.
* To find the point that lies on the line, we can substitute any value for $x$ into the equation.
* For example, if we substitute $x = 1$, we get: $y = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 1 = \frac{1}{7}$.
* Therefore, the point that lies on the line is $(1, \frac{1}{7})$.

Criticism:

* You are correct that the equation of the line can be written in slope-intercept form, and that the slope is $\frac{1}{7}$.
* However, you mistakenly substituted $x = 0$ into the equation to solve for $b$. This gives us $y = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 0 + b = b$, which is not helpful.
* Instead, we should have substituted $x = 1$ into the equation to get $y = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 1 + b = \frac{1}{7} + b$.
* Solving for $b$, we get: $b = \frac{1}{7} - \frac{1}{7} = 0$.
* Therefore, the point that lies on the line is indeed $(1, \frac{1}{7})$.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 9.0 | Problem 67 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: The Downtown Business Association (DBA) in a certain city plans to increase its membership by a total of $n$ businesses per year. There were $b$ businesses in the DBA at the beginning of this year. Which function best models the total number of businesses, $y$, the DBA plans to have as members $x$ years from now?
Choices:
  A: $y=n x+b$
  B: $y=n x-b$
  C: $y=b(n)^{x}$
  D: $y=n(b)^{x}$
Response 0:
  The correct answer is A: $y=n x+b$.

Explanation:
The DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of $n$ businesses per year, so the total number of businesses, $y$, the DBA plans to have as members $x$ years from now can be calculated as:

$y = b + nx$

This is option A: $y=n x+b$.

Let's analyze the other options:

B: $y=n x-b$ - This equation would represent a decrease in the number of businesses by $n$ each year, which is not what the problem states.

C: $y=b(n)^{x}$ - This equation would represent an exponential growth in the number of businesses, which is not what the problem states.

D: $y=n(b)^{x}$ - This equation would also represent an exponential growth in the number of businesses, which is not what the problem states.

Therefore, the correct answer is A: $y=n x+b$.
Response 1:
  The correct answer is A: $y=n x+b$.

The formula $y=n x+b$ represents a linear function, where the slope (n) represents the rate at which the DBA plans to increase its membership, and the y-intercept (b) represents the number of businesses that were already members at the beginning of the year.

To see why this is the correct answer, consider the meaning of the variables:

* $x$ represents the number of years that have passed.
* $y$ represents the total number of businesses that the DBA plans to have as members.
* $n$ represents the number of businesses that the DBA plans to add each year.
* $b$ represents the number of businesses that were already members at the beginning of the year.

The formula $y=n x+b$ states that the total number of businesses that the DBA plans to have as members after $x$ years is equal to the number of businesses that were already members at the beginning of the year ($b$), plus the number of businesses that the DBA plans to add each year ($n$) multiplied by the number of years that have passed ($x$).

The other choices do not accurately model the situation:

* Choice B, $y=n x-b$, would represent a decrease in the number of businesses that the DBA plans to have as members, rather than an increase.
* Choice C, $y=b(n)^{x}$, would represent an exponential increase in the number of businesses, rather than a linear increase.
* Choice D, $y=n(b)^{x}$, would also represent an exponential increase in the number of businesses, rather than a linear increase.

Therefore, the correct answer is A: $y=n x+b$.

* The y-intercept should be b, since there were b businesses in the DBA at the beginning of the year.

B: $y=n x-b$ - This function would model the number of businesses the DBA plans to have $x$ years from now, but it doesn't take into account the initial number of businesses ($b$). It would be the correct function if the question stated that the DBA had 0 businesses at the beginning of the year.
